column13: Fortescue implement, maintain and continually improve an Environmental Management System (EMS) aligned with ISO14001. The EMS is implemented across the company's operational sites, development projects, exploration activities and corporate offices, where Fortescue maintains operational control concerning the environmental impacts.

column13: In FY23, $278,000 was invested in baseline surveys for the Belinga project. The results of these surveys are informing the design of the Belinga project, allowing for consideration of the environment in which we are to operate. Infrastructure will be located to avoid critical biodiversity such as waterways, significant tree species, fauna habitat and heritage, where practicable.
column20: Biodiversity, baseline surveys, environmental consideration

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity

column13: The management plan identifies potential impacts on the conservation of significant fauna. It ensures effective management and monitoring measures for species including the Pilbara olive python, night parrot, northern quoll, greater bilby, ghost bat, Pilbara leaf-nosed bat and several migratory bird species.

column13: The Noise Management Plan ensures that noise levels associated with our rail and port activities comply with statutory requirements and acceptable standards and do not impact noise-sensitive receptors, including native fauna.

column6: Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity
column13: In FY23, Fortescue undertook biodiversity surveys spanning vast areas of the Pilbara, with over $4.1 million spent on environmental baseline studies to broaden the company's knowledge of the affected environment. Highlight includes the effect of decarbonisation activities, detailed surveys for flora and fauna, and species-specific focused surveys.

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column7: Fortescue waste includes non-mineral waste, hazardous materials, mineral waste, and tailings.

column13: Fortescue waste management approach aims to reduce waste through the prevention, reduction, recycling and reuse of waste produced across all sites. Fortescue continues investigating options to minimise the volumes of non-mineral general waste being sent to landfills.
column20: Waste management approach, waste reduction, waste prevention

column13: Non-mineralized waste generated at the company's sites, including steel, wood, rubber, food packaging, used oil, and office waste, was recycled through third parties, collected on-site for internal reuse, or recycled through Containers for Change.
column20: Non-mineralised waste, recycle, internal reuse

column13: Fortescue is collaborating with Tyre Stewardship Australia. They aim to identify viable recycling opportunities for used tyres from our Pilbara operations.
column20: Collaboration, tyre recycling, Tyre Stewardship Australia

column13: The Waste Management Plan aims to ensure that the disposal and management of waste do not adversely impact environmental values or the health, welfare and amenity of people and also details the key management actions to achieve the planÃ¢ÂÂs objectives.
column20: Waste management plan, waste management, waste disposal

column13: FY23, Fortescue initiated a pilot program to trial a baler unit at our Christmas Creek warehouse to divert recyclable waste from our landfill facilities. The baler unit can be used to bale either cardboard or soft plastic materials, allowing these materials to be quickly and safely transported off-site for recycling at suitable recycling facilities. Ultimately, Fortescue aims to install balers across our operations to target up to 1,200 tonnes of waste for diversion from the company's landfill facilities.
column20: Baler unit, waste diversion, cardboard and plastic waste

column13: Fortescue established a return program in partnership with the supplier, including a commitment from the supplier to provide sturdy, reusable hardwood pallets. The program planned to divert around 1,700 pallets from landfills each year, reducing costs and demonstrating a strong commitment to circularity.
column20: Flocculant Pallet, return program, circularity

column8: Chemical and Hydrocarbon Management Plan and Spills Procedures
column13: The Chemical and Hydrocarbon Management Plan includes measures to minimize the potential environmental impacts of chemical and hydrocarbon transport, storage, handling and disposal. The Hazardous Materials Management and Chemical and Hydrocarbon Spills Procedures outline key risks and specific management actions.
column20: Environmental impact, chemical and hydrocarbon disposal, chemical and hydrocarbon spill procedures

column13: Tailings storage facilities (TSFs) are designed, built, operated and closed in line with regulatory requirements. By applying the minimum requirements outlined by the Western Australian Department of Mines, Industry Regulation and Safety (DMIRS) and the Australian National Committee on Large Dams (ANCOLD), as well as applying international best practices, Fortescue minimizes any environmental and community impacts, and ensure operational efficiency, eliminating the risk of catastrophic failure Ã¢ÂÂ the uncontrolled release of tailings to the environment.
column20: TSF, requirements compliance, environmental impacts

column13: Tailings Management Plan (TMP) provides a consistent approach and the minimum requirements, systems and accountabilities to maintain the safety and integrity of the company's TSFs. The TMP complements the commitments of the company's Tailings Management Policy and the intent of the Global Industry Standard on Tailings Management (GISTM).
column20: TMP. TSF, GISTM

column13: Fortescue implemented internal TSF monitoring and surveillance programs that include daily, fortnightly, monthly and quarterly visual inspections and instrumentation surveillance monitoring and alarm systems. The TSFs are inspected annually by the Engineer of Record (Design Engineer) and undergo annual independent audits as per the DMIRS requirements.
column20: TSF, monitoring and surveillance programs, DMIRS requirements
